plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous tree known for its large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers that appear before the leaves, creating a spectacular early spring display.
plants.location: Temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere; widely cultivated in gardens across Europe, North America, and Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer Magnolia blooms before its leaves emerge, ensuring its showy flowers are highly visible and accessible to early pollinators.

plants.name: Clintonia borealis
plants.description: A perennial wildflower native to North American deciduous forests, featuring clusters of small yellow-green flowers that give way to striking bright blue berries.
plants.location: Northeastern United States and Canada, in cool, shaded woodlands
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the blue 'beads' are actually berries that mature after blooming, giving the plant a second seasonal interest.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: A hardy, evergreen shrub known for its clusters of highly fragrant, showy flowers that bloom profusely during warm months.
plants.location: Mediterranean region, subtropical and tropical zones worldwide; often cultivated as an ornamental plant
plants.funFact: Oleander is extremely toxic if ingested, yet it has been used historically in traditional medicines with great caution.

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A striking flowering tree with bright red, spiky blossoms resembling a rooster's comb; it thrives in subtropical regions and is celebrated as a national flower in Argentina and Uruguay.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to summer (May to August)
plants.location: South America (Argentina, Uruguay); also grown in subtropical gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: The vibrant red flowers attract hummingbirds and other pollinators, playing a vital role in the local ecosystem.
